stem: The patient is exhibiting signs of sepsis. Review the electronic health record and highlight the findings that support this diagnosis.

itemContext.sbar: S: John Smith, 78-year-old male, admitted three days prior for pneumonia, currently on IV Vancomycin and Ceftriaxone. B: History of COPD and hypertension. Noted increased work of breathing and altered mental status during the shift. O: At 07:00, temperature 38.9°C, heart rate 122 bpm, respiratory rate 28, blood pressure 88/52 mmHg, SpO2 90% on 2L NC. Patient is lethargic and confused. Urine output decreased to 20 mL/hr. Erythematous IV site on right forearm with purulent drainage. Labs show WBC 18,000/mm3, Lactate 4.5 mmol/L. A: Suspect sepsis secondary to pneumonia and possible IV site infection. Requesting blood cultures, lactate level, and fluid bolus. Will notify provider STAT if condition deteriorates or concerning changes occur.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: WBC: 18,000/mm3 (High), Lactate: 4.5 mmol/L (High), Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL (High), BUN: 35 mg/dL (High), Platelets: 140,000/mm3 (Low), Procalcitonin: 8 ng/mL (High). Blood cultures pending.

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
03:00: T 38.2°C, HR 110 bpm, RR 24, BP 96/60 mmHg, SpO2 93% on 2L NC
05:00: T 38.5°C, HR 115 bpm, RR 26, BP 90/55 mmHg, SpO2 91% on 2L NC
07:00: T 38.9°C, HR 122 bpm, RR 28, BP 88/52 mmHg, SpO2 90% on 2L NC

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Vancomycin 1g IV q12h (Last dose: 06:00), Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h (Last dose: 06:00), Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h PRN for fever, Normal Saline 500mL bolus (Ordered STAT)

tabs.title: Radiology
tabs.content: Chest X-ray from 3 days ago shows right lower lobe consolidation, consistent with pneumonia. No new infiltrates noted.

rationale.correct: Elevated WBC count (18,000/mm3) indicates the body is fighting an infection. Elevated Lactate (4.5 mmol/L) suggests tissue hypoperfusion and anaerobic metabolism. Elevated Creatinine (2.1 mg/dL) and BUN (35 mg/dL) point to acute kidney injury, possibly due to decreased perfusion from sepsis. Low Platelets (140,000/mm3) can be a sign of disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC), a complication of sepsis. Elevated Procalcitonin (8 ng/mL) is a strong indicator of bacterial infection and sepsis. Hypotension (BP 88/52 mmHg) is a key sign of septic shock due to vasodilation and decreased systemic vascular resistance. Tachycardia (HR 122 bpm) is the body's attempt to compensate for decreased perfusion. Tachypnea (RR 28) is the body's attempt to increase oxygenation and compensate for metabolic acidosis. Fever (38.9°C) is a systemic inflammatory response to infection, mediated by cytokines. The purulent drainage from the IV site indicates a localized infection, which can be a source of sepsis. Altered mental status (lethargy and confusion) suggests decreased cerebral perfusion and is a sign of organ dysfunction. Decreased urine output (20 mL/hr) indicates decreased renal perfusion and function.
rationale.incorrect: While other values in the EHR are important for overall patient assessment, the highlighted findings are the most direct indicators supporting a diagnosis of sepsis. Overlooking key lab values or vital signs can lead to a delay in treatment and worsen the patient's condition. Failing to recognize the significance of each indicator in the context of sepsis can result in an incomplete assessment.
clinicalPearls: Early recognition of sepsis is critical for improved patient outcomes. Use tools like qSOFA or SIRS criteria to aid in early detection.
Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention, following the 'Surviving Sepsis Campaign' guidelines.
Monitor trends in vital signs and lab values, as subtle changes can indicate worsening sepsis.
Always consider the source of infection and implement appropriate source control measures.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus solely on the elevated temperature and overlook other critical indicators like lactate, blood pressure, and platelet count, leading to an incomplete assessment of the patient's condition. They might also miss the significance of the IV site infection as a potential source of sepsis.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Encourage students to use a systematic approach, like the SOFA or qSOFA score, to assess for sepsis and to consider the constellation of findings rather than relying on a single data point. Emphasize the importance of identifying potential sources of infection and assessing for organ dysfunction.

mnemonic.title: S.E.P.S.I.S.
mnemonic.expansion: Slurred speech or confusion, Extreme shivering or muscle pain/fever, Passing no urine (in a day), Severe breathlessness, I feel like I’m going to die, Skin mottled or discolored
